item.title: Mamdani Names Transit Chief Whose Mandate Is to Improve Bus Service
item.description: As commissioner of the department of transportation, Michael Flynn will seek to implement one of the new mayor’s central campaign planks.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Dana Rubinstein

media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani introduced Michael Flynn, left, as his Transportation Department commissioner after the mayor’s swearing-in ceremony at the old City Hall subway station.

item.title: Predicciones 2026: así creemos que será la vida
item.description: Los ‘teléfonos tontos’ como símbolos de estatus, una guerra contra el contenido de baja calidad creado por IA y las apuestas por ‘The Real Housewives’ deberían hacer que el próximo año sea interesante.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Amy Li para The New York Times

item.title: Líderes del Departamento de Justicia habrían presionado para acusar a Abrego Garcia
item.description: La publicación de una serie de correos electrónicos suscitó dudas sobre si el departamento había engañado a un juez al decirle que los fiscales locales habían actuado solos al acusar a Abrego Garcia.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Extractos de los correos electrónicos parecían sugerir que los dirigentes del Departamento de Justicia habían desempeñado un papel más importante en la presentación de los cargos de lo que los fiscales han reconocido hasta ahora.

item.title: Why New York City Needs Someone Like Mamdani
item.description: The new mayor is an entirely familiar type of New York politician.
item.dc:creator: Kim Phillips-Fein

media:content.media:credit:
Photo illustration by The New York Times. Source photographs by Bettmann/Getty Images;
Damon Winter/The New York Times.

item.title: A Trump Security Is Empty, Mr. Zelensky
item.description: Ukraine’s president should stop pressing for U.S. security guarantees and pursue more effective means of self-protection.
item.dc:creator: Philip H. Gordon

item.title: Quote of the Day: Keys to City of New York Hop Hudson to Honorees
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 1, 2026.

item.title: How Japanese Scallops Became a Pawn in Diplomatic Tensions With China
item.description: Beijing is using a ban on the humble mollusk to punish Japan over its apparent willingness to defend Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 1, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 1, 2026.

item.title: See the First Iceberg of the Times’s Trip to Antarctica
item.description: For Antarctic veterans and novices alike, the first sighting of an iceberg on an expedition stays “closest to your heart.”
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Zohran Mamdani Is Sworn In as Mayor of New York City
item.description: Zohran Mamdani officially took office as mayor after the New Year’s Eve ball drop, in a private ceremony held at a shuttered relic of the city’s subway.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani was officially sworn in as mayor of New York City at the old City Hall subway station early Thursday.

item.title: NYT Crossword Hints for Dec. 31, 2025
item.description: Topher Booth makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
item.dc:creator: Deb Amlen

media:content.media:description: Eyes on your own crossword, please.

item.title: Ukraine Did Not Target Putin’s Home, C.I.A. Finds
item.description: The assessment rebutted a claim that the Russian leader made to President Trump in a phone call this week.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called Russia’s claim “a complete fabrication intended to justify additional attacks against Ukraine, including Kyiv, as well as Russia’s own refusal to take necessary steps to end the war.”

item.title: Historic Snowstorm Blankets Syracuse Just in Time for the New Year
item.description: Syracuse, N.Y., has received nearly twice its usual monthly amount of snow in December.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk and Samantha Latson

media:content.media:description: A street in Syracuse’s downtown area, known as Armory Square, was still covered in snow after the city’s second snowiest day on record.

item.title: Oil Tanker Fleeing the Coast Guard Now Listed in Russian Ship Database
item.description: The listing could make it more challenging for U.S. forces to board the ship, which an arm of the Kremlin’s maritime authority says is now flying the Russian flag.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Department of Homeland Security, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: A U.S. military helicopter flying over the Panama-flagged Centuries, which was intercepted in the Caribbean Sea. American officials have suggested that they intend to seize another ship, Bella 1, which they are currently tracking.

item.title: Coast Guard Searches for Survivors After More Boat Strikes
item.description: The U.S. military attacked a convoy of three boats in the eastern Pacific on Tuesday, and two more on Wednesday, as part of the Trump administration’s campaign against people suspected of drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A Coast Guard cutter in San Juan, P.R. An undetermined number of people survived strikes by the U.S. military on boats in the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Must Return Command of California National Guard to Newsom, Court Rules
item.description: The ruling is a win for Gov. Gavin Newsom, who has vigorously opposed President Trump’s moves to control California’s National Guard since the summer.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall

media:content.media:description: California National Guard troops on patrol at a federal building during protests in Los Angeles in June.

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Syria Kills Security Officer in New Year’s Eve Attack
item.description: The attacker likely had links to the Islamic State and was possibly targeting a Christian church in the center of Aleppo, according to a government spokesman.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Hussam Hammoud
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:description: A view of Aleppo, Syria, where a suicide bomber struck on Wednesday.

item.title: In Hearing Transcript, Jack Smith Defends Decision to Indict Trump
item.description: The former special counsel accused President Trump of “exploiting” violence on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an interview released by House Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jack Smith, the former special counsel, during a break in a closed-door deposition before the House Judiciary Committee earlier this month.

item.title: New Year’s Eve Crowds Brave Cold at NYC’s Times Square to Ring in 2026
item.description: The New Year’s Eve celebration drew spectators from around the world to New York City, despite cold and blustery weather.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack

media:content.media:description: By midafternoon crowds were jammed into Times Square waiting for the midnight ball drop.

item.title: On His Last Day, Adams Drops From View but Still Flexes His Muscle
item.description: Mayor Eric Adams had one public appearance on his schedule, but that didn’t stop him from naming a third charter commission in the last hours of his administration.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times

item.title: 53 Fascinating Facts of 2025
item.description: Each day, Times Insider editors scour the newspaper for the most interesting facts to appear on our pages. This year, tidbits about plastic recycling, whale sharks and crab Rangoon enlightened and entertained us.
item.dc:creator: Times Insider Staff and Mogu Takahashi

item.title: Mamdani Names Top Deputies for Child Care, Operations and Climate
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect, announced several key appointments who could help implement central promises of his agenda, including universal child care.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson

media:content.media:description: Emmy Liss, a veteran education leader, will be the director of New York City’s child care office.

item.title: In Chief Justice’s Annual Report, a History Lesson and Embrace of Independence
item.description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. did not directly address the tensions between the Trump administration and federal judges who have blocked the president’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

media:content.media:description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in May. By tradition, he releases his report about the state of the nation’s courts on the last day of the year.

item.description: tktktkt
item.dc:creator: Desiré Van Den Berg

media:content.media:description: A new oil processing facility at Tengiz--part of a nearly $50 billion expansion that has boosted the field’s capacity to 1 million barrels a day.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Trump Move to Revoke Deportation Protection for Thousands of Migrants
item.description: The ruling found that the administration’s cancellation of the protections for migrants from Honduras, Nepal and Nicaragua was illegal.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

media:content.media:description: Activists outside the federal courthouse in San Francisco in March rallying in support of preserving the Temporary Protected Status program.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in January
item.description: The first month of 2026 includes the latest Harlan Coben adaptation and the return of “Bridgerton.”
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

media:content.media:description: Yerin Ha in a scene from Part 1 of Season 4 of “Bridgerton.”

item.title: Jacqueline de Ribes, Tastemaker and Fashion Avatar, Dies at 96
item.description: One of few people in the world of style who could legitimately claim the status of icon, she dressed to impress even before she became a designer.
item.dc:creator: Ruth La Ferla

media:content.media:credit: Horst P. Horst/Condé Nast, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Jacqueline de Ribes in 1953. She designed clothes for herself and for a socially prominent clientele.

item.title: Sabotage Suspected in Cutting of Undersea Cable, Finnish Police Say
item.description: The authorities seized the Fitburg, a cargo ship that was en route from Russia to Israel when it sliced the cable in the Gulf of Finland.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Johanna Lemola

media:content.media:description: The Fitburg, a 132-meter-long cargo ship, was anchored after being seized by the Finnish authorities in Kirkkonummi, Finland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Mamdani Reverses Call to End Mayoral Control of NYC Public Schools
item.description: The mayor-elect’s turnaround came as he selected Kamar Samuels to lead New York City’s school system at a precarious moment.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson

media:content.media:description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani named Kamar Samuels as New York City’s schools chancellor. He starts on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Abandons Efforts to Deploy National Guard to 3 Major Cities
item.description: The troops had nearly no presence in two of the cities, Portland and Chicago. But the decision signaled a retreat, at least for now, in one of the president’s most audacious attempts to test his power.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: National Guard troops in Los Angeles in June. President Trump abandoned his effort to deploy the Guard there on Wednesday.

item.title: T Magazine’s Most-Read Art and Culture Features From 2025
item.description: A look at Japan’s microseasons, a retrospective on Gen X and more: These were readers’ 15 favorite stories.
item.dc:creator: T Magazine

item.title: Mamdani’s Man-of-the-People Style Could Present Security Challenges
item.description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, gregarious with constituents and vilified by a range of critics, is taking office at a time of anxiety about political violence.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani’s mayoral campaign hired private security after receiving threats. As mayor, he will have a police detail assigned to protect him.

item.title: Trump’s Veto of Water Project Is His Latest Targeted Hit on Colorado
item.description: The president seems to be at war with the Democratic-led state as he raises the pressure on Colorado leaders to release a convicted election denier, Tina Peters, from state prison.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

media:content.media:credit: RJ Sangosti/The Denver Post, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Arkansas Valley Conduit would provide clean water to 50,000 Colorado residents by diverting water from the Arkansas River, seen here at the base of the dam of the Pueblo Reservoir.

item.title: Meet the Ship Taking Us to Antarctica
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong gives a tour of the Araon, the South Korean icebreaker that will take him, our photographer and a team of scientists to Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Leila Medina, Sutton Raphael and Adam Hogan

item.title: Zohran Mamdani Is Sworn In as the Mayor of New York City
item.description: Zohran Mamdani was sworn in as the mayor of New York City in the first moments of New Year’s Day.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling and Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: Georgia Judge Dismisses Racketeering Charges Against ‘Cop City’ Activists
item.description: Dozens of protesters had been indicted after the state attorney general said that their movement amounted to a violent criminal enterprise.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Sean Keenan

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: For nearly two years, activists against the “Cop City” police training center camped in trees and clashed with law enforcement.

item.title: Venezuela detiene a estadounidenses en medio de la creciente presión de EE. UU.
item.description: El número de ciudadanos estadounidenses detenidos en Venezuela ha aumentado desde el inicio de la campaña militar y económica de Estados Unidos contra el presidente Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Annie Correal and Edward Wong

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, en un mitin en Caracas, la capital, a principios de este mes.

item.title: Mohammad Bakri, 72, Outspoken Palestinian Actor and Director, Dies
item.description: His work, including the 2002 documentary “Jenin, Jenin,” exposed the often harsh realities of life experienced by his fellow Arabs in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Most of Iran Shuts Down as Government Grapples With Protests and Economy
item.description: Amid mounting street protests, businesses, universities and government offices stayed closed Wednesday under government orders, in 21 of 31 provinces, including Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Sanam Mahoozi

media:content.media:description: Tehran on Wednesday as businesses, universities and most government offices were told to close.

item.title: President Macron of France Backs Social Media Restrictions for Children
item.description: French lawmakers are expected next month to discuss a ban on social media for children. In his New Year’s Eve address, the French president restated his support for restricting their access.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic

media:content.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France.

item.title: Trump’s Tangled Web of Deal-Making, Policy and Riches
item.description: The president, his family and some of their closest associates have engaged in a sprawling campaign of deals that stretches across industries and the globe.
item.dc:creator: Lazaro Gamio and Amy Schoenfeld Walker

item.title: ‘Swipe, Swipe’: New Yorkers Give the MetroCard a Public Funeral
item.description: There were few tears at a funeral for the MetroCard, which included chants of “swipe, swipe” and an urn.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

media:content.media:description: The MetroCard (a Mets fan, according to this framed image) was given a somber send-off in Washington Square Park in Manhattan on Wednesday after three decades of service.

item.title: Richard Smallwood, 77, Choral Leader and Composer of Gospel Hits, Dies
item.description: He sold millions of albums with the Richard Smallwood Singers, and his songs, many influenced by classical music, were recorded by stars like Whitney Houston.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

media:content.media:description: Richard Smallwood with his gospel chorus performing at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan in 2005. He wrote and arranged the group’s music, played piano and sang baritone.

item.title: 64 imágenes que definieron el año en las artes
item.description: Bad Bunny, Addison Rae, Audra McDonald, una clase de cotillón, Bing el perro y muchos más protagonizan las fotografías encargadas este año por nuestros editores de imagen.
item.dc:creator: Maridelis Morales Rosado, Laura O’Neill, Jolie Ruben and Amanda Webster

item.title: Venezuela Detains U.S. Citizens Amid Trump Administration’s Growing Pressure
item.description: The number of American citizens held in Venezuela has grown since the start of the U.S. military and economic campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Annie Correal and Edward Wong

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela at a rally in Caracas, the capital, earlier this month.

item.title: Research Library at NASA’s Goddard Space and Flight Center to Close Friday
item.description: Holdings from the library at the Goddard Space Flight Center, which includes unique documents from the early 20th century to the Soviet space race, will be warehoused or thrown out.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

media:content.media:description: The NASA Goddard Information and Collaboration Center in Greenbelt, Md. The 100,000 volume library will close Friday.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg’s Death: ‘Inexpressibly Sad’
item.description: Readers reflect on her life and the tragedies that have befallen the Kennedy family. Also: Protecting Planned Parenthood.

item.title: Manhattan Man, 80, Faces Homicide Charge After Sidewalk Shoving
item.description: Dana Escoffier was indicted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide in the death of Dean Whetzel, 82, a neighbor whom he had known for decades.
item.dc:creator: Miles G. Cohen

media:content.media:description: Dana Escoffier in his West Village apartment in 2000.

item.title: Thieves Make Off With Millions in German Bank Heist
item.description: The robbers stole valuables with an insured value of at least $36 million from a bank in Gelsenkirchen, western Germany.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze

media:content.media:description: The heist at first attracted little attention because the stolen contents were unclear.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg Submitted a Heartbreaking Essay to The New Yorker on Her Cancer Diagnosis, Fully Formed
item.description: When Tatiana Schlossberg submitted an essay to The New Yorker, it had not been assigned or even expected. It was accepted immediately and barely edited.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley

media:content.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg’s essay for The New Yorker, published online in November and in print this month, moved David Remnick, the magazine’s editor, with its “heart and intelligence and honesty,” he said.
